Package fr.cnrs.iees.identity

Interface Identity

All Known Subinterfaces:
Edge, Element, Node, TreeNode
All Known Implementing Classes:
ALDataEdge, ALDataNode, ALEdge, ALNode, ALReadOnlyDataEdge, ALReadOnlyDataNode, ElementAdapter, GUIDIdentity, PairIdentity, SimpleDataTreeNode, SimpleIdentity, SimpleReadOnlyDataTreeNode, SimpleTreeNode, TreeGraphDataNode, TreeGraphNode, TreeGraphReadOnlyDataNode, UidIdentity
public interface Identity

A unique identity within a given scope, to attach to some item that requires a unique identifier - typically, a graph node or edge.

Rules for implementing classes:

  1. The constructor must be protected so that it can only be called from an IdentityScope instance.
  2. They must override the Object.equals(Object) and Object.hashCode() methods. [not sure - check this]
Author:
Jacques Gignoux - 28 janv. 2019

  • Method Details

    • id

      String id()
      String version of this instance.
      Returns:
      a unique identifier, valid over the scope it was instantiated with.

    • scope

      IdentityScope scope()
      The scope that was used to instantiate this instance, within which it is guaranteed to be unique..
      Returns:
      the scope

    • universalId

      default String universalId()
      This identifier's unique identifier within the application it has been created. This method returns a concatenation of the scope identifier (as returned by IdentityScope.id()) with this instance id. The scope instance identifier is unique within the application that runs it.
      Returns:
      the universal id = scope id + item id

    • rename

      default void rename​(String oldId, String newId)

      Renames an id to another one - CAUTION: this is for very limited use cases (i.e. when editing the graph) and should be avoided as far as possible because it breaks the id immutability paradigm. The default implementation throws an Exception.

      WARNING: This is a typical example of a hack we would like to remove. Although there is no problem conceptually in having mutable identities, as long as their scope guarantees their uniqueness it makes implementation very difficult. Uniqueness is much easier to guarantee if identities are immutable. So don't rely on this method, don't use it, you have never seen it, ignore it, forget it if you didn't ignore it in the first time. It will certainly be removed one day.

      Parameters:
      oldId - The old Id string
      newId - The new Id string
